context.description: These tables respresents the the types of projects available into which you can generate a Web service or client. You cannot add or remove project types, however you can change the order in which they appear in the Web services wizard. This is useful if you are creating several Web services that use the same type of service or client project because you can set that service or client project type as the default. To change the order, select a project type and use the up and down arrows to move it within the list. Changing the order of the list does not restrict your ability to select any of the options. If you select the check box, by default the Web services wizard will generate the Web services server and client code into different EARs. It is recommended that you enable this feature.
Select the default Web server to be used for Web service creation.
Select the default server run-time environment to be used for Web service creation.
If you have chosen to install, start, or deploy the Web service, the server needs to be started before the wizard can proceed.
Select from the listed EAR projects.
Select from the listed Java beans.
Use this page to select the Java bean or class used to create the Web service.

Enter the name of the Java bean to be used to create the Web service. Defaults to the selected Java bean. Click Browse classes to view the bean class of the selected Java bean. The bean class is a model or template (an abstract data type) that can be instantiated to create objects with a common definition and therefore, common properties, operations, and behavior.
Click to view the bean class of the selected Java bean.
Browse to the correct Java bean to be used to create the Web service.

Use this page to select the WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document that will be used to create the Web service. By default WSDL validation is disabled. You can enable it through Preferences > Web Services > Wizard Validation.
Enter the path to a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Browse to the location of a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.

This table lists any issues the WSDL validator may have encountered while examining the specified WSDL file. By default WSDL validation is disabled. You can enable it through Preferences > Web Services > Wizard Validation.

This table lists any issues the WSDL validator may have encountered while examining the specified WSDL file. By default WSDL validation is disabled. You can enable it through Preferences > Web Services > Wizard Validation.
Click this button to stop the validation of the selected WSDL file.
Select the scenario configuration for runtime environments, servers, and projects.
This is the server-side runtime environment which the Web service will use.
This is the server-side server on which the Web service will run.
Select this view to see runtime/server combinations sorted by runtime.
Select this view to see runtime/server combinations sorted by server.
Select this view to explore available runtime/server combinations.
Select the project in which the Web service client will be created. The wizard will generate this project if it does not already exist.
Select from the listed project types the type of project that you want created to contain your Web service client.
Select from the listed project types the type of project that you want created to contain your Web service.
The sample Web application demonstrates how to code the proxy file.
If selected will launch the sample Web application in the Web browser.
The sample Web application demonstrates how to code the proxy file.
Click this button to add all the available methods to the Web service sample proxy.
Click this button to remove all the available methods to the Web service sample proxy.
Folder into which your Web service JSPs are deposited.
Click to find the folder into which your Web service JSPs are deposited.
Select an existing project into which your sample will be generated.
Folder into which the fully qualified proxy is generated. Defaults to the source folder inside of your Web project.
Select this check box to run the sample application on the server.
Select the EAR in which you want your Web service sample application created.
Use this wizard to add and remove handlers for a Web service. The order in which they are listed represents the order in which the handlers will be acted upon.
Use this wizard to add and remove handlers for a Web service. The order in which they are listed represents the order in which the handlers will be acted upon.
Use this wizard to add and remove handlers for a Web service. The order in which they are listed represents the order in which the handlers will be acted upon.

On this page select the artifact from which your Web client will be created, and the stages of Web services development that you want to complete: - Develop: this will create the client code - Assemble: this ensures that the project that will host the client gets associated to an EAR when required by the target application server - Deploy: this will create the deployment code for the client - Install: this will install the client on the chosen server - Start: this will start the server once the client has been installed on it - Test: this will provide various options for testing the client Select the server and runtime for your Web client, and whether or not you want to publish or monitor the service.

Monitor the Web service: this will send the Web service traffic through the TCP/IP Monitor, which allows you to watch the SOAP traffic generated by the Web service and to test this traffic for WS-I compliance.
Enter the URI to the WSDL, WSIL, or HTML file that will be used to generate the service
Select your server: the default server is displayed. If you want to deploy your service to a different server click the link to specify a different server.
Select your runtime: the default runtime is displayed. If you want to deploy your service to a different runtime click the link to specify a different runtime.

Select the service project: the project containing the project selected in your workspace is displayed. To select a different project and EAR click on the project link. Ensure that the project selected as the Client Web Project is different from the Service Web Project, or the service will be overwritten by the client's generated artifacts.
The Java bean client proxy that is generated provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.

Select the stages of Web services client development that you want to complete using the slider: - Develop: this will create the client code - Assemble: this ensures that the project that will host the client gets associated to an EAR when required by the target application server - Deploy: this will create the deployment code for the client - Install: this will install the client on the chosen server - Start: this will start the server once the client has been installed on it - Test: this will provide various options for testing the client
This allows you to overwrite files without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation when overwriting files.
Enter the required information to generate a standardized WSDL reference (WSIL) document in your project.
Enter the name of the WSIL document being generated, or accept the default.
Browse to the location of a WSDL or WSIL file from which the new WSIL document will be generated.
This lists all the WSDL URIs that will be included in the WSIL document.
Select the type of Web service you want to generate and any file and folder options for your Web service.
Allows you to overwrite files without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation when overwriting files.
Select to create folders and folder structures without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation.
The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select this check box to test the generated proxy.
Click to start the server. If you leave the box unchecked you will have to manually start the server.
Select the type of Web service you want to build. Your selection will affect the files available for selection.
Select the type of Web service you want to build. Your selection will affect the files available for selection.
Select this check box to launch the Web service in the Web Services Explorer in order to examine it.
Select this checkbox to launch the Web Services Explorer in order to publish the Web service to a UDDI registry.
The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select the client proxy type. The generated Java bean proxy provides a remote procedure call interface to the Web service.
Select to check out files without receiving a warning message asking for confirmation.
Select to launch the Web Services Explorer to allow you to publish the Web service.
If selected will launch the Web Services Explorer to allow you to publish the Web service.
Use this page to select the WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document that will be used to create the Web service.
Enter the path to a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Browse to the location of a WSDL, WSIL, or HTML document.
Enter the user name used for HTTP basic authentication.
Enter the password used for HTTP basic authentication.
